comments.commentBody: Somehow this is not an issue to which economics offers reasonable advice.  In fact, the more economics I understand the less relevant economists remarks are on almost any issue great or small.  It is a subject without (much) foundation in reality beyond the fact that people do indeed trade goods, money being one good among many.

That's true. My brother had a pet pig who ran with the dogs. He thought and acted as a dog. This pig had an actual smile  on his face!  When you look at photographs of pigs being raised for meat on these awful farms they are not smiling.
That's why the answer is to give up animal products completely. There is nothing to gain from supporting this horror. Milk also is a product of torture. Do your own research.

A compassionate society normally places human lives and reduction of suffering above profit-taking.

The trouble with considering global warming gasses, is that the 10,000 (approximately according to UN) people who die from toxic air each day, are conveniently ignored.

At over 4 million lives a year lost, one would think a holocaust of such magnitude would normally be newsworthy.
Just give up meat and then many many problems on this planet will resolve themselves. It's easier than trying to figure out a good way to eat meat. There is no good way to eat meat. It's a waste.

David Albuquerque:
wow, how condescending!

Maybe.

But cookie cutter mindless stuff like Dano's gushers:

"It is important to understand that denialists have no body of work to back their fringe ideology."

are sometimes too much.

Early in the morning after a night of work...

sas I agree.

Conservation is great and it is the way to go.

When I bought my house twenty years ago fiberglass had just gotten cheap so the builder put a foot of it all around the house. To the effect that it only cost as much to heat as an appartment.

To which I added an extra foot between floors, so I can listen to Mahler at concert levels at 3 am without waking anyone up (the amp heats the house as well, as does the computer...)
Look at this study in the context of the prior ones.  W.F. Ruddiman offers a useful perspective which suggests the current paper is not the entire story.
Thank you Wang Suya for your beautiful sentiments.

Malcolm NYC "Is this a poem?"

Kinda. Thanks.
Animal products are not good, natural and sustainable they are cruel, wasteful and completely destructive to our bodies  and the planet.

"healthy crop of denialist claptrap?"

nothing makes a crop grow like water ... and plenty of co2.

MIke Mangan: "We didn't want anything. YOU want our money, to put it simply."

Oh, you didn't want anything? Just the status quo: mercury, particulates, NO2, CO2 warming pollution, changing the chemistry of the ocean, continued profitable pollution with all costs externalized, the easy life for this generation with no thought to the future.... no, you didn't want anything, did you?

Hi Pete,

This is why I no longer come here often -- and I WILL NOT SUBSCRIBE TO THE NYT until it gets its act together. When did newspaper become blogs? It's absolutely pathetic.

Andy,

Does it bother you that the comment section for your blog seems to have provided the appropriate conditions for producing a healthy crop of denialist claptrap? This appears to be the case from the standpoint of both the number of repetitive, ill-informed comments (e.g., “trick to hide the decline,” out of context, once again) and the high incidence of meritless denialist comments being “recommended.” I am in no position to prove that denialists are financially or otherwise encouraged to send in emails or that they “pad” the recommendation numbers, but with the type of educated and left of center readership that the NY Times attracts, there is something about this that doesn’t pass the smell test. Really, are the denialists simply more industrious?

I am grateful that the First Amendment, e.g. a live lecture before a broad segment of a college community, shines a light on competing claims -- but it is truly tiresome to have to wade through all of the nonsense denialists clog up your comment page with. You can count on denialists to never explain how their theories account for decade after decade growing warmer in synch with increased carbon in the atmosphere, etc. Instead, they provide an extravagant detour of why Al Gore (James Hansen, Michael Mann, etc.) is fundamentally corrupt.

So do you see a need for a more insightful, constructive and honest exchange. If so, how do we get there? (I know I'm getting slammed and offer no apologies to the denialists.)

Defending the quality of the scientific literature is not an attack on free speech, it a responsibility of qualified scientists.

By his statement, Michaels demonstrates that he is not qualified.

$4 million fossil-fuel man Michaels claims Mann fired the first shot.

Mann has been dodging bullets from fossil-fuel shills for over a decade -- give us a break!

"I wholeheartedly disagree with any attempt to inhibit it but I fear that Mann fired the first shot here."

Er, how so?

Patrick Michaels, a climate scientist affiliated with the libertarian Cato Institute, sent this reaction by e-mail:

Mike Mann should be able to speak anywhere or at any time that he wants. He should also be able to write anything he wants. And he should not attempt to organize campaigns to punish scientific journal editors who publish things he disagrees with. Free speech is free speech. I wholeheartedly disagree with any attempt to inhibit it but I fear that Mann fired the first shot here.
Oh, how it must rankle. Let's hope it all gets sorted out.
me too

Frankly I will no longer be able to donate to Komen until I see a certified list of where their donations actually go proving that they are not a secret donor to some superpac. I have absolutely no faith in them, none, zero, zilch. My wife wishes that she could get her donations back. At this time I have no idea how they will ever be able to prove themselves.That's just how it is. It is a new policy that we have started recently.

Women persisted throughout these hardships and overcame all of it. Women will be professional footballers in the US. Just not this year and probably not with the WPS.

This is the reason why women's soccer is magnificent. With its well behaved crowds and its easy to get tickets, we don't just watch people kicking a ball into a net, we watch people triumphing over history.

I know this isn't the answer you're looking for, but there really is no answer. Losing a pro league is a bad, no way around that. All we can do as fans is keep the faith and keep spending money.

Here's an excellent interview of Abby:
http://espn.go.com/espnw/more-sports/7538588/us-soccer-said-deal-dan-bor...

A explanation of why the WPS is terrible:
http://espn.go.com/espnw/commentary/7528161/women-professional-soccer-br...

And a history of English women football that will make you feel better about the WPS.
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-humber-16814902

Metz didnt make him an offer.  That's what we get when the owner is financially impotent  The Wilpons are a sad lot and don't deserve owning a major league club.  Shame on Selig for supporting his old time sweetheart.  Baseball looks bad and no wonder less and less people consider it their favorite sport.  It makes me sick to lose Reyes without even a whimper.

I was just going to say something along these exact lines. I've also taught computer literacy courses. The course I taught covered the basics of computers, networking, etc. and also had a lab portion that covered Microsoft Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and Access.

I can not even begin to describe how computer illiterate the average college student is. Sure, they all grew up using computers but they treat them like appliances. They use them only to do the very small set of things that they are interested in. So for most this entails using Facebook and maybe a little web surfing. Even those that have webmail accounts have the hardest time attaching a file to an email. In the same way we don't expect most people to be proficient in accessing the various menu settings on their television these students aren't familiar with the details of how to use a computer.

A huge thank you to everyone who has contributed to this project so far. The response has been incredible — humbling, in fact. I'm really proud that so many people understand the scope and severity of the illegal wildlife trade, and are willing to put not only their name behind this project but also their hard-earned cash. We're well on our way to producing a landmark photographic book that will, in my view, help bring this trade to an end. While I'm confident that we'll reach our goal, there is still a little distance to go, so I ask that you please keep passing around the www.emphas.is link. Thanks again, everyone. Patrick
he's been wrong so far, and he's still wrong.  Pats win this one easily because of Giants severe over-confidence....
Best of luck to you. The league maybe away, but the fans are still here.

I'm sorry Jake but you might say I'm more like a Clint Eastwood type, much younger, but in terms of this new technologies in social media. I'm in it only to let others have easier access to me, no specifics and not for entertainment. I do not have a twitter account so you get the profile.

In my view its no different from any celebrity who knows how much they owe their fans. Only with FB, Mark always has the option of going beyond spoken appreciation and be the first to actually match words with an unprecedented gesture, 1 share per FB user. Will that make me rich? Heck no but he will certainly be all the more richer for it in my eyes.

So, when we're all out of work, and no one's bothering to look anymore because there are no jobs - we'll have 0% unemployment. What a feat!

Always the easiest way to drive the number down...

Because of the gradually improving outlook for the economy, Mitt Romney has had to repeatedly modify his core campaign message. First, he said President Obama was making the economy worse. (It wasn't getting worse.) Then Romney said that the president wasn't making the economy better. (It was improving, albeit slowly.) Now he says the economy is improving, but it's no thanks to Obama. Well, what can he say? "Nice job, Mr. President?"

Constantly changing his message feeds the Mitt Romney as flip-flopper meme and raises havoc with objective measures of his truth-telling. http://www.panderingpoliticians.com/2012/02/truth-quotient-rankings-poli...

There were 132,952,000    people working in December.  There were 130,456,000    people working in January.  That is a loss of 2.5  million jobs...  and the unemployment rate went down.  Sounds like someone is lying.....  his name starts with and O and ends in an A.....

Underreported is that many unemployed homeowners can't relocate because they can't sell their house. I switched to being a month-to-month renter after I became unemployed in January 2011 so that I could be mobile. I ended up leaving Colorado for Missouri for a job last month. I'd still be unemployed if I weren't mobile. THe housing boom, I think, is keeping people unemployed since they aren't mobile to relocate.

Some of the unemployed rent their houses, then move for a job. I know a journalist who got laid off in Fresno, got a job in Oregon more than a year later, and now rents out his Fresno house. But it appears that is the exception.
